earth/Avoid-Waste-with-R's.title: Avoid Waste with R's
earth/Avoid-Waste-with-R's.content:
The hierarchy of waste management:

reduce: Buy only what is needed. Buy less often.
reuse: Buy high quality and reuse items before throwing them in the trash.
recycle: If you trash items, put them in the correct recycling bins.

Further Râ€™s:

refuse Actively counteract waste. Unsubscribe paper ads.
repair: Fix stuff before tossing it.
rot: Compost organic waste.

See CircleWaste: What are the 5 Râ€™s of Waste Management?.

info/Classification-Error-Types.title: Classification Error Types
info/Classification-Error-Types.content:
There are two error types in classification problems: False positives (FP) and false negatives (FN). I find it more convenient to think in False Alarms (FP) and Missed Hits (FN).



                  
                  Example: â€œIs a person infected?â€ 
                  
                

â†’ classify each person into infected/healthy

Error 1 (FP), False Alarm: classify â€œinfectedâ€ but is healthy
Error 2 (FN), Missed Hit: classify â€œhealthyâ€ but is infected



Classification tests can be tuned to favor one error over the other:

Favor false alarms: HIV test â†’ You do not want to miss an infected person
Favor missed hits: Airbag trigger â†’ You do not want an exploding airbag in your face when driving normally

For example, the sensor in the car for triggering the airbag is designed to favor missed hits but almost never produce a false alarm. Thus, the airbag may only trigger 50% of the time when having a bad accident but should never trigger when bumping into a pot hole. The rationale is that an airbag that unexpectedly explodes into your face during normal driving leads to accidents in over 50% of the time.

Default task that is not in inbox is â€œAction Itemâ€
Tasks with due date is calendar or start with â€œEvent: â€œ
Await tasks start with â€œawaitâ€ â€œw84â€, â€œConditionâ€
Communication tasks are â€œcallâ€
References/Resources start with â€œresâ€  (not urgent)
Goals, future, later, plan

Alternative Names
CCORE: Captureâ€“Clarifyâ€“Organizeâ€“Reviewâ€“Engage
DOER: Dump/Deposit/Deferâ€“Organizeâ€“Engageâ€“Review
Câ€“DOER: Collect, Direct, Organize, Engage, Review
Clever-DOER
C3ER: Capture, Clarify, Categorize, Engage, Review
CALL â€“ Collectâ€“Arrange/Aimâ€“Lâ€“Learn
CODE â€“ Collectâ€“Organizeâ€“Doâ€“Evaluate
COWS â€“ Collect â€“ Arrange â€“ Work â€“ Scan
Old CORE Process 2023-08-16
A method for processing documents and information based on GTD. CORE stands for:

Capture: Store any input at a central â€œinboxâ€. URLs, ToDos, Notes, Talks, PDFs, Quotes, etc.
Organize: Go through the inbox and define next step for each item:

Do it now: If it is a task that requires less than 2min, execute immediately.
Delegate: Forward the item to another person.
Defer: Put into the correct list: act, aw8, calendar, later, projects, resources, someday


Review/Reflect:

Daily: Get your inbox to zero. Review tasks or Reduce information.
Weekly: Update your lists/info.


Execute: Express/Export information in own words. Engange/Execute a task.

Capture: Out of your brain
Capturing allows you to get something off your mind quickly. When a thought hits your brain, it can (and will) suppress all other thoughts until you do something about it. You should transfer any new input into your inbox within few seconds.

Your brain is made for having ideasâ€¦ not for storing them.

Clarify

Do it now: If it is a task that requires less than 2min, execute immediately.
Delegate: Forward the item to another person.
Defer: Put into the correct list: act, aw8, do, due, event, horizon, maybe, idea, later, projects, resources, someday

Organize
Organize each input by providing context (time, location, topic). Put into the correct list:

Action-Items: A list of single-step actions that need to be done.
Calendar: For events that will happen at a specific time.
Projects: Everything that requires multiple steps is a separate list.
Maybe Someday: Not forgetting. Might become relevant in the future.
Waiting-on: Everything that depends on external events.
References: All materials that could help at some point in time.


The wrong way to organize information is by where you found it. The right way is to organize by location where you will use the information. â€“ Tiago Forte

info/DOER-Process.title: DOER Process
info/DOER-Process.content:
A method for processing documents and information based on GTD. DOER stands for
DOER Overview

Dump & Decide: Dump any input as short note into a central â€œinboxâ€. URLs, ToDos, Notes, Talks, PDFs, Quotes, etc. After dumping, decide whether to

Defer: Postpone the processing to step 2 (Organize)
Delegate: Forward the item to another person.
*Do it now: If it is a task that requires less than 2min, execute immediately.


Organize: Once you have time, put each item left into its correct list/location:

Planner: For action items. Sort into check, do, plan. Tag projects
Calendar: For reminders, recurring, Meeting, Event
Incubator: Goals, Ideas, Visions, Leads, Jots
Library: Article, Ideas, Resources


Engage: Execute a task, for example, Express/Export information in own words.
Review/Reflect:

Daily: Get your inbox to zero. Review tasks or Reduce information.
Weekly: Update your lists/info.



Workflow Details
1. Dump: Get it out of your brain
Dumping allows you to get something off your mind quickly. When a thought outside the current context hits your brain, it is exhausting to keep it present in the background. It is likely that you either forget the thought or it interferes with your current thinking context. You should transfer any new input into your inbox within few seconds.

Your brain is made for having ideasâ€¦ not for storing them.

Then decide what should happen:
* Defer: Postpone the processing to step 2 (Organize)
* Delegate: Forward the item to another person.
* *Do it now: If it is a task that requires less than 2min, execute immediately.
2. Organize
Organize each input by providing context (time, location, topic). Put into the correct list:

Action-Items: A list of single-step actions that need to be done.
Calendar: For events that will happen at a specific time.
Projects: Everything that requires multiple steps is a separate list.
Maybe Someday: Not forgetting. Might become relevant in the future.
Waiting-on: Everything that depends on external events.
References: All materials that could help at some point in time.


The wrong way to organize information is by where you found it. The right way is to organize by location where you will use the information. â€“ Tiago Forte

â†’ Use alive, check, do, plan, stored
3. Engage
Work on the different items and projects.
4. Review
Go through your lists and clean up. Get your inbox to zero.
Differences to GTD

GTD has 5 steps: 1. collect, 2. clarify, 3. organize, 4. review, 5. engage.
DOER removed the â€œclarifyâ€ step by splitting it into â€œdecisionâ€ and â€œadding contextâ€ and including these parts in â€œDump & Decideâ€ and â€œOrganizeâ€.
In DOER you immediately do or delegate tasks once they come to your mind if this takes less then 2 minutes.
In DOER, the execution phase comes before the review phase as this seems to be more intuitive.

info/Resolutionâ€“Precisionâ€“Accuracy.title: Resolutionâ€“Precisionâ€“Accuracy
info/Resolutionâ€“Precisionâ€“Accuracy.content:
Since no measurement of a physical quantity is infinitely accurate, it is important to determine how much a measured value will most likely deviate from the unknown, true value of the quantity. There are three important metrics for the quality of a repeated measurement:

ResolutionÂ is the fineness to which an instrument can be read.
PrecisionÂ is the fineness to which an instrument can be readÂ repeatedly and reliably.
Accuracy is how close a measured value is to the actual value.

Eine Aussage wird dadurch als wahr belegt, weil sie von einer hohen AutoritÃ¤t oder Mehrheit geÃ¤uÃŸert wurde. Gleiches gilt fÃ¼r Widerlegung durch gering AutoritÃ¤t oder Minderheit.

Argumente sollten sich auf Fakten beziehen und nicht darauf, welche oder wie viele Personen eine bestimmte Meinung haben. Es ist allerdings zulÃ¤ssig sich auf Personen mit fachlicher Expertise zu berufen, sofern diese einen neutralen Standpunkt haben. Im Beispiel hat


ğŸ—¿ Strohmann-Argument {#strohmann}
Eine Aussage wird stark verzerrt/vereinfacht/abgewandelt und so ein Argument angegriffen, welches der Sprecher in dieser Weise gar nicht vertritt.

Nur weil es wichtigere Probleme oder Argumente gibt, bedeutet das nicht, dass ein kleineres Problem oder Argument irrelevant oder falsch ist. Im Gegenteil: LÃ¶st man zuerst kleinere Probleme, kann man schneller und langfristiger von der Verbesserung profitieren.

Argumente, die sich auf ein Spektrum beziehen, gehen oft implizit von einem â€angemessenen Gradâ€œ aus. Jemand der den Ausbau des Mobilfunknetzes fordert, mÃ¶chte vermutlich weder einen einzelnen Mast, noch auf jedem Hausdach einen eigenen Mast bauen, sondern eine â€angemessene Mengeâ€œ dazwischen.

mind/The-37-percent-Stopping-Rule.title: The 37% Stopping Rule
mind/The-37-percent-Stopping-Rule.content:
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ”¬ E. Regnath Â· ğŸ“† Jun. 2023 Â· ğŸ§ª v-0.2
How to choose wisely if you know little: Observe 25%â€“37% of options, then select the next best.
The optimal strategy for selecting the best car, phone, or romantic partner is easy to follow and proven by math â€“ yet known by few. If N is the number of options, T the maximum time to decide, and P the probability that you get the option if you select it, we can derive the optimal strategies that are shown in the following table.





























ConditionProblemStrategyKnown N, P=1InterviewsObserve 37% of N, choose next bestKnown T, P=1PurchasingObserve 37% of T, choose next bestKnown T, P=0.5MarriageObserve 25% of T, choose next best

Known N and P=1: This is called the secretary problem in which you interview N applicants for a secretary position and need to decide to reject or accept each applicant directly after the interview. P = 1 means that an applicant will take the job if you make an offer. The optimal strategy to maximize the chance for selecting the best candidate
Known T and P=1:  If the number of options is unknown, we can apply the same rule to the timeframe we have: Observe options (as they come in) for 37% of the time, then select.



                  
                  Good Choice Variant: 
                  
                

If the goal is to maximize the chance for a good selection instead of the chance of hitting the best choice, a shorter observation ratio of 25% is better.


ğŸ“š References

Algorithms to Live By: The Computer Science of Human Decisions, 2017
Up and Atom: â€œWhen to Quitâ€, YouTube

society/Meeting-Manifesto.title: Meeting Manifesto
society/Meeting-Manifesto.content:
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ”¬ E. Regnath Â· ğŸ“† Mar. 2023 Â·  ğŸ§ª Draft 0.1 Â·
All meetings consume time and money. Many meetings waste time and money. Here are 12 rules for running a meeting efficiently.

Share Goal & Agenda upfront: What should be the outcome? What will be discussed? Not answering both questions means the meeting is unnecessary.
Flag people as optional: Flag most people as optional and let them decide whether the meeting is valuable to them. Allow them to leave early so that they dare to join. Hint: If you can check mails during a meeting, you are optional. If everyone can check mails, the meeting is optional.
Be prepared: You donâ€™t need five people to watch one person look up numbers in a report.
Make notes: Decisions and Action Items that are not written down and tracked will be forgotten.
Start on time: Waiting for latecomers might seem like a nice gesture but is disrespectful towards the people that joined on time. Either truly start 9:00 or schedule for 9:05.
Discuss with â‰¤5 people: If you have more than 5 people, your meeting should be a single-person show (presentation/status report), a parallel collaboration (e.g. conceptboard), or a voting. Remember: On TV, you never see discussion rounds with more than 5 people and there are reasons for it.
Discuss at least three ideas. One idea is bad, two ideas is an argument, three ideas is a discussion.
Have a parking lot for off-topics: Whenever a discussion starts drifting off, make a note of the idea/concern and deal with it later. Stay focused on the agenda/outcome unless the off-topic is a blocking issue for everyone.
Be clear, not clever: Avoid technical jargon and use concise and easy words. Not everyone has the same knowledge background, language/pronunciation skills or WiFi stability.
Silence is confirmation. Do not wait for positive verbal feedback. Ask for concerns and/or collect votes using the Approval Voting System (ask for all the OKs).
Practice active listening. People wonâ€™t hear your idea unless youâ€™ve heard theirs.
Donâ€™t follow these rules. Follow the principles they reflect.

ğŸ“š References

www.linkedin.com/pulse/see-below-6-rules-productivity-from-elon-musks-leaked-lauren-mcdonald/

4: Ich will es! Es ist mein Liebling, macht mich sehr glÃ¼cklich

â†’ Getestet, funktioniert sehr gut. Aber: nicht geeignet um genauere Abstimmungen vorzunehmen




                  
                  Option B: -3 .. 3 (ohne 0) 
                  
                

FÃ¼r z.B. Wollen wir Spiel X spielen?

-3: Stark dagegen ()
-2: Dagegen (Will Nicht essen)
-1: Eher dagegen aber OK  (Zur Not essen)
1: Eher dafÃ¼r aber Ok falls nicht (Leichter Appetit)
2: DafÃ¼r (Will essen)
3: Stark dafÃ¼r ()

Probleme:

Nur 3 positive MÃ¶glichkeiten sind zu wenig (Tendenz zur Mitte)
-1 schwierig. Wenn es bedeutet (â€œwill nichtâ€), dann sind -2/-3 fast egal. Wenn -1 als erstes positives gilt (â€œZur Not esse ichâ€) ist der Zahlenwert nicht intuitiv & groÃŸer Sprung von 1 zu -1





                  
                  Option C: -4, -2, 0,1,2,3 
                  
                

Mittelwert ist 0 und -4 in einer Zweierabstimmung ist eine Art â€œVetoâ€. 4 â€œpositiveâ€ Werte, 0 = bevor es weggeschmissen wird. â†’ Warum nicht -3..3?

-4: Gar kein Bock (ich bin raus/dumme Idee)
-2: Dagegen
0: Mir egal, bin mit beidem einverstanden
1: Eher dafÃ¼r aber Ok falls nicht
2: DafÃ¼r
3: Stark dafÃ¼r

â†’ Vorteil: Liefert leichter ein eindeutiges Ergebnis bei gerader Anzahl an Personen. Respektiert, dass es schlimmer ist, etwas zu machen was man nicht will, als etwas nicht zu machen was man will.




                  
                  Oder ganz anders?

tech/File-based-Version-Control.title: File-based Version Control
tech/File-based-Version-Control.content:
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ”¬ E. Regnath Â· ğŸ“† 2024-04 Â· ğŸ§ª v1.0
Do you have files and folder names including terms like final, final2, old, or v2? Then file-based version control might be for you.
Version control systems have been proven to be highly effective in handling the chaos of ever changing text files and open-source development would not be possible without it. However, not everyone is a software developer, has only text files, or wants to use extra tools (like git).
Luckily, we can implement a simple version control for everyone and everything just by adding a â‰¤4 letter version tag to a filename based on 4 simple rules.
4 Rules to tame them all

A file without a version tag is the latest working version (think â€œstagingâ€ in git)
To â€œcommitâ€ a version for yourself, save a copy of the working version and add a version tag with leading zero (e.g. -v01) to the file name.  Version tags start with -v01 and strictly increase. After -v09 continue with -v010. Version tags must be unique â€“ if two file have the same tag, they must be identical.
Never ever edit a file with a version tag! Either continue editing the latest working version, replace it with a copy of any committed version and remove the version tag (â€œroll-backâ€), or â€œbranchâ€ by creating a second working version with a working tag instead of a version tag, which could be -w03 if you edit -v03.
To â€œreleaseâ€ a version that will be shared with a larger group, add a release tag of the form -v1.0 without leading zeros and with a dot. Any version can become a release, e.g. turning v07 into v1.2 is fine.

Thatâ€™s it. Most of these rules should be intuitive and easy to follow. The only crucial rule you need to remember and strictly enforce is rule 3, so letâ€™s repeat it:


                  
                  â€œNever ever edit a file with a version tag!â€ 
                  
                

If you want to edit a version, close the file (if open), make a copy, remove the tag and only then open it for editing. Follow this process strictly as editing an open version file with the intent to â€œsave asâ€ later is error-prone â€“ forget it once, or hit Ctrl + S by accident and the system breaks.


Rationales behind the rules

Rule 1 makes sure that you do not need to rename any files in order to start with the system. Any regular file without a version tag is by definition already in its latest working version. You can either keep it untouched or edit it â€“ full flexibility.
Rule 2 defines the main ideas of the scheme: We add a special tag to any version we want to identify throughout time. This is enables us to keep track of progress, inspect previous versions, roll-back to a version, or agree on versions with others (e.g. â€œdid I sent you v03 or v04?â€). Starting with a leading zero ensures that we can distinguish versions for internal tracking from releases that are shared with a larger group.
Rule 3 makes sure that the scheme is robust, meaning that version tags are unique. The whole point of versions is to uniquely identify a certain state so there must not be different files with the same tag. And â€œmust notâ€ means never â€“ otherwise the trust in the system is broken. To ensure that you should never open a version file
Rule 4 makes sure that the scheme is compatible with exiting conventions of software releases and thus intuitively understood by many people. At the same time release tags without leading zero and dot are clearly distinctive from internal version tags. More technically, the two tag forms have a Levenshtein distance of â‰¥2, which allows us to detect simple mistakes. For example, -v010 and -v1.0 are both valid forms but -v10 (e.g. accidently produced by typo) would be invalid and requires clarification and correction.

Additional Ideas

In a collaborative environment, you could also add the name of the editor behind the version tag. Just make sure that the version tag increases not matter what. For example, if Alice and Bob take turns in editing a file we would see -v03-bob, -v04-alice, -v05-bob.
Store all files with version tags in a versions subfolder.
You may jump to -v010 to indicate versions after a release v1.0

ğŸ“š References

Wikipedia: Software Versioning

tech/Non-Functional-Requirements.title: Non-Functional Requirements
tech/Non-Functional-Requirements.content:
A short overview of possible NFRs.

Functional requirementsÂ specifyÂ whatÂ the system should do. E.g. â€œDisplay the last user ID that logged into the system.â€
Non-functional requirementsÂ specifyÂ howÂ the system should be. E.g. â€œThe system shouldÂ be secureÂ against code injection attacks.â€Â 

NFRs have many different names and can be classified according to different hierarchies/dimensions. According toÂ ISO/IEC 25010:

However, some categories seem very related (compatibility & portability), some popular terms are missing (sustainability, transparancy, safety, privacy) and the overview does not provide definitions. The following list/tree is an attempt to give some concise structure to NFRs but different projects might prefer different structures.Â Â Further NFR overviews can be found onÂ Wikipedia.
ğŸ›´Â Efficiency:Â Consume few resources to produce/operate.
This can be distinguished according to the resource type:

ğŸ•‘Â Time:

â³ Latency: Time to respond to one request.
ğŸš¿ Throughput: Maximum amount of processed requests per time interval.


â¬œÂ Space:

ğŸ’¾ Storage: How much data is stored?
âœ‰ Message: How much data is transmitted?


âš¡Â Energy:Â How much energy is required to produce/operate?
ğŸ’°Â Cost:Â How much money is required to produce/operate?

â›“Â Reliability:Â Ensure system remains operational.

ğŸŒÂ Availability:Â Avoid and mitigate failures to increase â€œuptimeâ€.

ğŸ›¡ Robustness: Do not crash on unexpected requests.
ğŸª‚ Fault Tolerance / Redundancy / Resilience: Recover from failures.
ğŸ“ˆ Scalability: Handle increased load and avoid stalling/dropping requests.


ğŸ”’ Security:Â Avoid and mitigate misuse/tampering.

ğŸ‘â€ğŸ—¨ Confidentiality: data should not be revealed to unintended recipients.
âœ‚ Integrity: data should not be changed during transmission.
ğŸ›‚ Authenticity: data must originate from the correct entity.



ğŸ”§ Universality/Flexibility:Â How many problems can the system solve?

ğŸ’±Â Interoperability/Compatibility: Ability to interact with other systems.
ğŸ§³ Portability/Adaptability: Ability to operate in different environments.
â™»Â Reuseability: Ability to reuse parts for other systems.
ğŸ“ˆ Scalability: Ability to scale efficiently with growing input.

ğŸš§Â Maintainability:Â How easy can a system be repaired/modified?

ğŸ² Determinism / Testability: Ability to reproduce behavior.
ğŸ” Transparency / Verifiability: Ability to analyze behavior.
ğŸ§© Modularity: Separation into independent parts to lower complexity.
â• Extensibility: How easy can the system be extended?
ğŸ“– Documentation: How well is the system documented?

ğŸ‘¥ Usability: How easy can the system be used?

â–¶ Simplicity/Learnability: How intuitive is the system?
ğŸŒ Localization: Available and adapted to many languages/locations.
â™¿ Accessibility

âš–ï¸ Compliance (Trustability?):
This section is not well-defined yet. Some of these points might better fit somewhere else.

ğŸŒ±Â Sustainability: Minimizing negative impact on theÂ environment,Â societyÂ andÂ economy
ğŸ­ Privacy / GDPR / SSI: Ability to self-manage/protect personal data. Users cannot be identified.
ğŸ‘‰ Accountability: Ability to trace actions uniquely to each entity/agent.
â›‘ Safety: Protect users against harmful conditions or events.
ğŸ“ Standardization: Rely on well-defined components and processes.

âœ” Correctness:

This section might be related toÂ functional requirements.


ğŸ¯ Accuracy: Response should be close to true value. Related to Precision/Resolution.
ğŸ”¬ Sensitivity: System should detect weak inputs.
â± Freshness: Response should be recent.

tech/OAuth.title: OAuth
tech/OAuth.content:
OAuth2 is a protocol to share access tokens between different parties. OAuth is not an authentication protocol because it says absolutely nothing about the user. It is only concerned about tokens.

ğŸ¯ Goal: An application (e.g. Printing) can access a content provider (e.g. Cloud Gallery) on behalf of a user by passing an access token.

Advantage: The service does not need to know any details about the user (e.g. username and password).
Both OAuth 1.0a & 2.0 supportÂ two-legged authentication, where a server is assured of a userâ€™s identity, andÂ three-legged authentication, where a server is assured by a content provider of the userâ€™s identity. Three-legged authentication is where authorization requests and access tokens come into play, and itâ€™s important to note that OAuth 1 has those, too.
Protocol Details
The usual flow of the protocol is as following:
 +--------+                               +---------------+
 |        |--(A)- Authorization Request ->|   Resource    |
 |        |                               |     Owner     |
 |        |<-(B)-- Authorization Grant ---|    (User)     |
 |        |                               +---------------+
 |        |
 |        |                               +---------------+
 |        |--(C)-- Authorization Grant -->| Authorization |
 | Client |                               |     Server    |
 |  App / |<-(D)----- Access Token -------|     (IDP)     |
 | Service|                               +---------------+
 |        |
 |        |                               +---------------+
 |        |--(E)----- Access Token ------>|    Resource   |
 |        |                               |     Server    |
 |        |<-(F)--- Protected Resource ---|(Content Prov.)|
 +--------+                               +---------------+


TheÂ applicationÂ requests authorization to access service resources from theÂ user
If theÂ userÂ authorized the request, theÂ applicationÂ receives an authorization grant
TheÂ applicationÂ requests an access token from theÂ authorization serverÂ (API) by presenting authentication of its own identity, and the authorization grant
If the application identity is authenticated and the authorization grant is valid, theÂ authorization serverÂ (API) issues an access token to the application. Authorization is complete.
TheÂ applicationÂ requests the resource from theÂ resource serverÂ (API) and presents the access token for authentication
If the access token is valid, theÂ resource serverÂ (API) serves the resource to theÂ application



                  
                  Printing online Photos 
                  
                

Alice (Resource Owner) has stored Photos (Resource) at a Cloud Storage (Resource Server). She wants to enable a company PrintMagic (Client) to access a certain folder and print the photos.


Components
Roles

Resource Owner: Entity (e.g. User) that owns resources and wants a service to use it.
Resource Server: The content provider for the resources, e.g. a cloud storage.
Client: An service that wants to access resources of the user.
Authorization Server: An Identity Provider that authenticates the resource owner.

Data
OAuth 2 uses and authorization grant and two types of tokens:

authorization grant: Can be one of three types:

Authorization Code: used with server-side Applications (most common)


Client Credentials: used with Applications that have API access
Device Code: used for devices that lack browsers or have input limitations


refresh token. The refresh token becomes the permanent password equivalent, and itâ€™sÂ only ever transmitted over SSL.
access token: To access content, the service exchanges the refresh token for a short-lived access token. That way all sniffable HTTP accesses are made with a token that will expire. Google uses 5 minute expiration on their OAuth 2 APIs.

Further Details

OpenID Connect is an authentication framework based on OAuth2
Google provides an API key for any app (e.g. auth0.com) that wants to use their authentication service.
Google Console: There you receive the API key for your application


ğŸ“š References

An Introduction to OAuth 2 | DigitalOcean
OAuth 2.0: Benefits and use cases â€” why? - Stack Overflow

Why character diagrams instead of images?
They are small, portable and text inlined diagrams that look decent even in a text editor. They are a good choice for Markdown-based systems and can also be pasted into many chat applications that have monospace font.

UFT-8 diagrams do not need to be pure text. We embed them into HTML and so we can use CSS and JS to enable additional features.

Select fonts for different character ranges
Use JS to reduce/increase font size until it fits into screen width

tech/Universal-Project-Folder-Structure.title: Universal Project Folder Structure
tech/Universal-Project-Folder-Structure.content:
I have many projects. Some are research, some are code, some are physical DIYs, and some are pure documentation. Most projects start small but quickly grow into a mess, if I do not enforce a clean structure on them. What if we could organize most projects with a similar folder structure, such that it is easy for you and for others to navigate the folders and understand where each file belongs?
Here is my proposal for a folder structure that can be applied on almost all your file-based coding projects:
project-name/ 
â”‚  
â”œâ”€ build/         the final generated product  
â”œâ”€ docs/          description of the product  
â”œâ”€ lib/           external dependencies maintained elsewhere
â”œâ”€ make/          toolchain for making the product  
â”‚  â”œâ”€ config/  
â”‚  â””â”€ tools/  
â”œâ”€ res/           static resources like images/audio  
â”‚  â”œâ”€ img/  
â”‚  â”‚  â””â”€ dia/  
â”‚  â””â”€ css/  
â”œâ”€ src/           blueprint of the product**,** e.g. code  
â”œâ”€ test/          quality assurance of the product  
â”œâ”€ tmp/           ALL temporary generated files  
â”‚  â”œâ”€ objs/  
â”‚  â””â”€ logs/  
â”œâ”€ xtra/          extra files not belonging elsewhere  
â”œâ”€ Makefile       Trigger for setup/build/install  
â””â”€ README.md      Information entry point

Features â€” Why should you use this?

most important user folders (build,Â docs) are sorted to the top. (you could also renameÂ buildÂ toÂ appÂ orÂ bin)
least important folders (tmp,Â extra) are sorted to the bottom.
clear separation of dynamic files (src) and static files (res,Â lib)
clear separation of own code (src) and foreign code (lib)
one folder for all temporary files with a descriptive name. Everyone will know that files inÂ tmpÂ can be deleted any time.
names reflect categories and not specific formats (e.g.Â imgÂ notÂ jpg/png,Â makeÂ notÂ cmake/waf)
names start with a different letter which makes keyboard navigation fast (except forÂ tmp)
names are short, which keeps overall path lengths short
names are common and should be intuitive for most developers
